summary: In this criminal appeal, Ellis Tamakloe challenged his conviction and 10-year sentence for attempted exportation and possession of 695g of cannabis without lawful authority. The Supreme Court of Ghana upheld the lower courts' decisions, affirming that circumstantial evidence sufficiently established Tamakloe's possession and control of the parcel containing the drugs. The Court found that Tamakloe's act of personally filling in consignee details on the airway bill and failing to question the incorrect sender's address (Friesland Company) supported an irresistible inference of guilt. The Court emphasized that knowledge and intent—key elements of mens rea—can be inferred from conduct, and held that the prosecution met the burden of proof beyond reasonable doubt using circumstantial evidence in line with established legal principles.
verdict: Conviction and sentence upheld on both counts.
citations: The State v Anani Fiadzo [1961] 1 GLR 416-419
Bonsu alias Benjilo v The Republic [2000] SCGLR 112
Warner v Metropolitan Police Commissioner [1969] 2 A.C.
R v Smith Dearsley and PCC 494
R v Gleed (1917) 12 CR App. R. 32a
Archbold Criminal Pleading, Evidence and Practice (36th ed.)
rationaleHighlights: Circumstantial evidence must lead to an irresistible inference of guilt incompatible with innocence.
Physical possession of a drug parcel, coupled with control and conduct, supports constructive possession.
Mens rea can be inferred from established facts and behavior, not requiring direct proof.
Failure to correct a false sender's address on an airway bill undermines a claim of innocent involvement.
The burden of proof lies with the prosecution to establish guilt beyond reasonable doubt, even in absence of direct evidence.
